00020 sub DEBUG_MESSAGE {
00021     my @msg = @_;
00022     $PG->debug_message("---- ".join(" ",caller())." ------", @msg,"__________________________");

00024 sub WARN_MESSAGE{
00025     my @msg = @_;
00026     $PG->warning_message("---- ".join(" ",caller())." ------", @msg,"__________________________");

00113 sub LABELED_ANS {
00114   my @in = @_;
00115   my @out = ();
00116   #prepend labels with the quiz and section prefixes.
00117   while (@in ) {
00118     my $label    = shift @in;
00119     $label       = join("", $PG->{QUIZ_PREFIX}, $PG->{SECTION_PREFIX}, $label);
00120     $ans_eval = shift @in;
00121     push @out, $label, $ans_eval;
00122   }
00123   $PG->LABELED_ANS(@out); # returns pointer to the labeled answer group
00124 }

00183 sub RECORD_EXTRA_ANSWERS {

00192 sub NEW_ANS_ARRAY_NAME {  # this keeps track of the answers within an array which are entered implicitly,
00193                           # rather than with a specific label
00194         return "" if $PG_STOP_FLAG;
00195         my $number=shift;
00196         $main::vecnum = -1;
00197         my $row = shift;
00198         my $col = shift;
00199 #       my $array_ans_eval_label = "ArRaY"."$number"."__"."$vecnum".":";
00200         my $label = $PG->{QUIZ_PREFIX}.$PG->{ARRAY_PREFIX}."$number"."__"."$vecnum"."-"."$row"."-"."$col"."__";
00201 #       my $response_group = new PGresponsegroup($label,undef);
00202 #       $PG->record_ans_name($array_ans_eval_label, $response_group);
00203 #       What does vecnum do?
00204 #       The name is simply so that it won't conflict when placed on the HTML page
00205 #       my $array_label = shift;    
00206         $PG->record_array_name($label);  # returns $array_label, $ans_label

00213 sub NEW_ANS_ARRAY_ELEMENT_NAME {   # creates a new array element answer name and records it   
00214                                           
00215         return "" if $PG_STOP_FLAG;
00216         my $number=shift;   
00217         my $row_num = shift;
00218         my $col_num = shift;
00219         if( $row_num == 0 && $col_num == 0 ){
00220             $main::vecnum += 1;     
00221         }
00222 #       my $ans_label = "ArRaY".sprintf("%04u", $number);
00223         my $ans_label = $PG->new_array_label($number);
00224         my $element_ans_label = $PG->new_array_element_label($ans_label,$row_num, $col_num,vec_num=>$vecnum);
00225         my $response = new PGresponsegroup($ans_label,$element_ans_label, undef);
00226         $PG->extend_ans_group($ans_label,$response);
00227         $element_ans_label;
00228 }

00235 }

00242 sub CLEAR_RESPONSES {
00243     my $ans_label  = shift;
00244 #   my $response_label = shift;
00245 #   my $ans_value  = shift;
00246     if (defined ($PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$ans_label}) ) {
00247         my $responsegroup = $PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$ans_label}->{response};
00248         if ( ref($responsegroup) ) {
00249             $responsegroup->clear;
00250         } else {
00251             $responsegroup = $PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$ans_label}->{response} = new PGresponsegroup($label);    
00252         }
00253     }
00254     '';
00255 }
00256 sub INSERT_RESPONSE { 
00257     my $ans_label  = shift;
00258     my $response_label = shift;
00259     my $ans_value  = shift;
00260     my $selected   = shift;
00261     # warn "\n\nanslabel $ans_label responselabel $response_label value $ans_value";
00262     if (defined ($PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$ans_label}) ) {
00263         my $responsegroup = $PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$ans_label}->{response};
00264         $responsegroup->append_response($response_label, $ans_value, $selected);
00265         #warn "\n$responsegroup responses are now ", $responsegroup->responses;
00266     }
00267     '';
00268 }
00269 
00270 sub EXTEND_RESPONSE { # for radio buttons and checkboxes
00271     my $ans_label  = shift;
00272     my $response_label = shift;
00273     my $ans_value  = shift;
00274     my $selected   = shift;
00275     # warn "\n\nanslabel $ans_label responselabel $response_label value $ans_value";
00276     if (defined ($PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$ans_label}) ) {
00277         my $responsegroup = $PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$ans_label}->{response};
00278         $responsegroup->extend_response($response_label, $ans_value,$selected);
00279         #warn "\n$responsegroup responses are now ", pretty_print($response_group);
00280     }
00281     '';
00282 }
00283 sub ENDDOCUMENT {
00284     # check that answers match
00285     # gather up PG_FLAGS elements
00286 
00287     $PG->{flags}->{showPartialCorrectAnswers}      = defined($showPartialCorrectAnswers)?  $showPartialCorrectAnswers : 1 ;
00288     $PG->{flags}->{recordSubmittedAnswers}         = defined($recordSubmittedAnswers)?     $recordSubmittedAnswers    : 1 ;
00289     $PG->{flags}->{refreshCachedImages}            = defined($refreshCachedImages)?        $refreshCachedImages       : 0 ; 
00290     $PG->{flags}->{hintExists}                     = defined($hintExists)?                 $hintExists                : 0 ;
00291     $PG->{flags}->{solutionExists}                 = defined($solutionExists)?             $solutionExists            : 0 ;
00292     $PG->{flags}->{comment}                        = defined($pgComment)?                  $pgComment                 :'' ;  
00293     $PG->{flags}->{showHintLimit}                  = defined($showHint)?                   $showHint                  : 0 ;  
00294  
00295     
00296     # install problem grader
00297     if (defined($PG->{flags}->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE})  ) {
00298         # problem grader defined within problem -- no further action needed
00299     } elsif ( defined( $rh_envir->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} ) ) {
00300         if (ref($rh_envir->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE}) eq 'CODE' ) {         # user defined grader
00301             $PG->{flags}->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} = $rh_envir->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE};
00302         } elsif ($rh_envir->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} eq 'std_problem_grader' ) {
00303             if (defined(&std_problem_grader) ){
00304                 $PG->{flags}->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} = \&std_problem_grader; # defined in PGanswermacros.pl
00305             } # std_problem_grader is the default in any case so don't give a warning.
00306         } elsif ($rh_envir->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} eq 'avg_problem_grader' ) {
00307             if (defined(&avg_problem_grader) ){
00308                 $PG->{flags}->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} = \&avg_problem_grader; # defined in PGanswermacros.pl
00309             }
00310         } else {
00311             warn "Error:  ". $PG->{flags}->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} . "is not a known program grader.";
00312         }
00313     } elsif (defined(&std_problem_grader)) {
00314         $PG->{flags}->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} = \&std_problem_grader; # defined in PGanswermacros.pl
00315     } else {
00316         # PGtranslator will install its default problem grader
00317     }
00318     
00319     # add javaScripts
00320     if ($rh_envir->{displayMode} eq 'HTML_jsMath') {
00321         TEXT('<SCRIPT> jsMath.wwProcess() </SCRIPT>');
00322     } elsif ($rh_envir->{displayMode} eq 'HTML_asciimath') {
00323         TEXT('<SCRIPT> translate() </SCRIPT>');
00324         my $STRING = join("", @{$PG->{HEADER_ARRAY} });
00325         unless ($STRING =~ m/mathplayer/) {
00326             HEADER_TEXT('<object id="mathplayer" classid="clsid:32F66A20-7614-11D4-BD11-00104BD3F987">' . "\n" .
00327                         '</object><?import namespace="mml" implementation="#mathplayer"?>'
00328             );
00329         }
00330     
00331     }
00332     TEXT( MODES(%{$rh_envir->{problemPostamble}}) );
00333   
00334     
00335     
00336     
00337     
00338     @PG_ANSWERS=();
00339 
00340     #warn keys %{ $PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH} };
00341     @PG_ANSWER_ENTRY_ORDER = ();
00342     my $ans_debug = 0;
00343     foreach my $key (keys %{ $PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH} }) {
00344             $answergroup = $PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$key};
00345             #warn "$key is defined =", defined($answergroup), "PG object is $PG";
00346             #################
00347             # EXTRA ANSWERS KLUDGE
00348             #################
00349             # The first response in each answer group is placed in @PG_ANSER_ENTRY_ORDER and %PG_ANSWERS_HASH
00350             # The remainder of the response keys are placed in the EXTRA ANSWERS ARRAY
00351             if (defined($answergroup)) {
00352                 my @response_keys = $answergroup->{response}->response_labels;
00353                 warn pretty_print($answergroup->{response}) if $ans_debug==1;
00354                 my $response_key = shift @response_keys;
00355                 #unshift @response_keys, $response_key unless ($response_key eq $answer_group->{ans_label});
00356                 # don't save the first response key if it is the same as the ans_label
00357                 # maybe we should insure that the first response key is always the same as the answer label?
00358                 # even if no answer blank is printed for it? or a hidden answer blank?
00359                 # this is still a KLUDGE
00360                 # for compatibility the first response key is closer to the old method than the $ans_label
00361                 # this is because a response key might indicate an array but an answer label won't
00362                 push @PG_ANSWERS, $response_key,$answergroup->{ans_eval};
00363                 push @PG_ANSWER_ENTRY_ORDER, $response_key;
00364                 push @KEPT_EXTRA_ANSWERS, @response_keys;
00365             } else {
00366                 #warn "$key is ", join("|",%{$PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH}->{$key}});
00367             }
00368     }
00369     push @KEPT_EXTRA_ANSWERS, keys %{$PG->{PERSISTENCE_HASH}};
00370     my %PG_ANSWERS_HASH = @PG_ANSWERS;
00371     $PG->{flags}->{KEPT_EXTRA_ANSWERS} = \@KEPT_EXTRA_ANSWERS;
00372     $PG->{flags}->{ANSWER_ENTRY_ORDER} = \@PG_ANSWER_ENTRY_ORDER;
00373     
00374     # these should not be needed any longer since PG_alias warning queue is attached to PGcore's
00375     # $PG->warning_message( @{ $PG->{PG_alias}->{flags}->{WARNING_messages}} );
00376     # $PG->debug_message( @{ $PG->{PG_alias}->{flags}->{DEBUG_messages}}   );
00377     
00378     
00379     warn "KEPT_EXTRA_ANSWERS", join(" ", @KEPT_EXTRA_ANSWERS), $BR     if $ans_debug==1;
00380     warn "PG_ANSWER_ENTRY_ORDER",join(" ",@PG_ANSWER_ENTRY_ORDER), $BR if $ans_debug==1;
00381     warn "DEBUG messages", join( "$BR",@{$PG->get_debug_messages} ) if $ans_debug==1;
00382     warn "INTERNAL_DEBUG messages", join( "$BR",@{$PG->get_internal_debug_messages} ) if $ans_debug==1;
00383     $STRINGforOUTPUT      = join("", @{$PG->{OUTPUT_ARRAY} });
00384     
00385     
00386     $STRINGforHEADER_TEXT = join("", @{$PG->{HEADER_ARRAY} }); 
00387     $STRINGforPOSTHEADER_TEXT = join("", @{$PG->{POST_HEADER_ARRAY} }); 
00388     # warn pretty_print($PG->{PG_ANSWERS_HASH});
00389     #warn "printing another warning";
00390 
00391     (\$STRINGforOUTPUT, \$STRINGforHEADER_TEXT,\$STRINGforPOSTHEADER_TEXT,\%PG_ANSWERS_HASH,  $PG->{flags} , $PG   );
00392 }

00432 #####################################
00433 # This is a model for plug-in problem graders
00434 #####################################
00435 # ^function install_problem_grader
00436 # ^uses PG_restricted_eval
00437 # ^uses %PG_FLAGS{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE}
00438 sub install_problem_grader {
00439     my $rf_problem_grader = shift;
00440     my $rh_flags = $PG->{flags};    
00441     $rh_flags->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE} = $rf_problem_grader if not_null($rf_problem_grader) ;
00442     $rh_flags->{PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE};
00443 }
00444 
00445 sub current_problem_grader {
00446     install_problem_grader(@_);
00447 }

00454 # ^function i
00455 # ^uses $_parser_loaded
00456 # ^uses &Complex::i
00457 # ^uses &Value::Package
00458 sub i () {
00459   #  check if Parser.pl is loaded, otherwise use Complex package
00460   if (!eval(q!$main::_parser_loaded!)) {return Complex::i}
00461   return Value->Package("Formula")->new('i')->eval;
00462 }
00463 
00464 # ^function j
00465 # ^uses $_parser_loaded
00466 # ^uses &Value::Package
00467 sub j () {
00468   if (!eval(q!$main::_parser_loaded!)) {return 'j'}
00469   Value->Package("Formula")->new('j')->eval;
00470 }
00471 
00472 # ^function k
00473 # ^uses $_parser_loaded
00474 # ^uses &Value::Package
00475 sub k () {
00476   if (!eval(q!$main::_parser_loaded!)) {return 'k'}
00477   Value->Package("Formula")->new('k')->eval;
00478 }

00489 # ^function abs
00490 # ^function sqrt
00491 # ^function exp
00492 # ^function log
00493 # ^function sin
00494 # ^function cos
00495 # ^function atan2
00496 #
00497 #  Allow these functions to be overridden
00498 #  (needed for log() to implement $useBaseTenLog)
00499 #
00500 use subs 'abs', 'sqrt', 'exp', 'log', 'sin', 'cos', 'atan2';
00501 sub abs($)  {return CORE::abs($_[0])};
00502 sub sqrt($) {return CORE::sqrt($_[0])};
00503 sub exp($)  {return CORE::exp($_[0])};
00504 sub log($)  {return CORE::log($_[0])};
00505 sub sin($)  {return CORE::sin($_[0])};
00506 sub cos($)  {return CORE::cos($_[0])};
00507 sub atan2($$) {return CORE::atan2($_[0],$_[1])};
00508 
00509 sub Parser::defineLog {eval {sub log($) {CommonFunction->Call("log",@_)}}};
00510 =head2 Filter utilities
00511 
00512 These two subroutines can be used in filters to set default options.  They
00513 help make filters perform in uniform, predictable ways, and also make it
00514 easy to recognize from the code which options a given filter expects.
00515 
00516 
00517 =head4 assign_option_aliases
00518 
00519 Use this to assign aliases for the standard options.  It must come before set_default_options
00520 within the subroutine.
00521 
00522         assign_option_aliases(\%options,
00523                 'alias1'    => 'option5'
00524                 'alias2'    => 'option7'
00525         );
00526 
00527 
00528 If the subroutine is called with an option  " alias1 => 23 " it will behave as if it had been
00529 called with the option " option5 => 23 "
00530 
00531 =cut
00532 
00533 
00534 # ^function assign_option_aliases
00535 sub assign_option_aliases {
00536     my $rh_options = shift;
00537     warn "The first entry to set_default_options must be a reference to the option hash" unless ref($rh_options) eq 'HASH';
00538     my @option_aliases = @_;
00539     while (@option_aliases) {
00540         my $alias = shift @option_aliases;
00541         my $option_key = shift @option_aliases;
00542 
00543         if (defined($rh_options->{$alias} )) {                       # if the alias appears in the option list
00544             if (not defined($rh_options->{$option_key}) ) {          # and the option itself is not defined,
00545                 $rh_options->{$option_key} = $rh_options->{$alias};  # insert the value defined by the alias into the option value
00546                                                                      # the FIRST alias for a given option takes precedence
00547                                                                      # (after the option itself)
00548             } else {
00549                 warn "option $option_key is already defined as", $rh_options->{$option_key}, "<br>\n",
00550                      "The attempt to override this option with the alias $alias with value ", $rh_options->{$alias},
00551                      " was ignored.";
00552             }
00553         }
00554         delete($rh_options->{$alias});                               # remove the alias from the initial list
00555     }
00556 
00557 }
00558 
00559 =head4 set_default_options
00560 
00561         set_default_options(\%options,
00562                 '_filter_name'  =>  'filter',
00563                 'option5'       =>  .0001,
00564                 'option7'       =>  'ascii',
00565                 'allow_unknown_options  =>  0,
00566         }
00567 
00568 Note that the first entry is a reference to the options with which the filter was called.
00569 
00570 The option5 is set to .0001 unless the option is explicitly set when the subroutine is called.
00571 
00572 The B<'_filter_name'> option should always be set, although there is no error if it is missing.
00573 It is used mainly for debugging answer evaluators and allows
00574 you to keep track of which filter is currently processing the answer.
00575 
00576 If B<'allow_unknown_options'> is set to 0 then if the filter is called with options which do NOT appear in the
00577 set_default_options list an error will be signaled and a warning message will be printed out.  This provides
00578 error checking against misspelling an option and is generally what is desired for most filters.
00579 
00580 Occasionally one wants to write a filter which accepts a long list of options, not all of which are known in advance,
00581 but only uses a subset of the options
00582 provided.  In this case, setting 'allow_unkown_options' to 1 prevents the error from being signaled.
00583 
00584 =cut
00585 
00586 # ^function set_default_options
00587 # ^uses pretty_print
00588 sub set_default_options {
00589     my $rh_options = shift;
00590     warn "The first entry to set_default_options must be a reference to the option hash" unless ref($rh_options) eq 'HASH';
00591     my %default_options = @_;
00592     unless ( defined($default_options{allow_unknown_options}) and $default_options{allow_unknown_options} == 1 ) {
00593         foreach  my $key1 (keys %$rh_options) {
00594             warn "This option |$key1| is not recognized in this subroutine<br> ", pretty_print($rh_options) unless exists($default_options{$key1});
00595         }
00596     }
00597     foreach my $key (keys %default_options) {
00598         if  ( not defined($rh_options->{$key} ) and defined( $default_options{$key} )  ) {
00599             $rh_options->{$key} = $default_options{$key};  #this allows     tol   => undef to allow the tol option, but doesn't define
00600                                                            # this key unless tol is explicitly defined.
00601         }
00602     }
00603 }
00604 
00605 =item includePGproblem($filePath)
00606 
00607  includePGproblem($filePath);
00608 
00609  Essentially runs the pg problem specified by $filePath, which is
00610  a path relative to the top of the templates directory.  The output
00611  of that problem appears in the given problem.
00612 
00613 =cut
00614 
00615 # ^function includePGproblem
00616 # ^uses %envir
00617 # ^uses &read_whole_problem_file
00618 # ^uses &includePGtext
00619 sub includePGproblem {
00620     my $filePath = shift;
00621     my %save_envir = %main::envir;
00622     my $fullfilePath = $PG->envir("templateDirectory").$filePath;
00623     my $r_string =  read_whole_problem_file($fullfilePath);
00624     if (ref($r_string) eq 'SCALAR') {
00625         $r_string = $$r_string;      
00626     }
00627 
00628     # The problem calling this should provide DOCUMENT and ENDDOCUMENT,
00629     # so we remove them from the included file.
00630     $r_string=~ s/^\s*(END)?DOCUMENT(\(\s*\));?//gm;
00631 
00632     # Reset the problem path so that static images can be found via
00633     # their relative paths.
00634     eval('$main::envir{probFileName} = $filePath');
00635     eval('$main::envir{fileName} = $filePath');
00636     # now update the PGalias object
00637     my $save_PGalias = $PG->{PG_alias};
00638     my $temp_PGalias = PGalias ->new( \%main::envir,
00639                                       WARNING_messages => $PG->{WARNING_messages},
00640                                       DEBUG_messages  => $PG->{DEBUG_messages},
00641     );
00642     $PG->{PG_alias}=$temp_PGalias;
00643     includePGtext($r_string);
00644     # Reset the environment to what it was before.
00645     %main::envir = %save_envir;
00646     $PG->{PG_alias}=$save_PGalias;
00647 }
00648 
00649 sub beginproblem;  # announce that beginproblem is a macro
00650 
00651 1;
00652 __END__

00659 # This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify it under
00660 # the terms of either: (a) the GNU General Public License as published by the
00661 # Free Software Foundation; either version 2, or (at your option) any later
00662 # version, or (b) the "Artistic License" which comes with this package.
00663 # 
00664 # This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but WITHOUT
00665 # ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS
00666 # FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See either the GNU General Public License or the
00667 # Artistic License for more details.

00669 
00670 =head1 NAME
00671 
00672 PG.pl - Provides core Program Generation Language functionality.
00673 
00674 =head1 SYNPOSIS
00675 
00676 In a PG problem:
00677 
00678     DOCUMENT();             # should be the first statment in the problem
00679     
00680     loadMacros(.....);      # (optional) load other macro files if needed.
00681                             # (loadMacros is defined in F<dangerousMacros.pl>)
00682     
00683     HEADER_TEXT(...);       # (optional) used only for inserting javaScript into problems.
00684     
00685     TEXT(                   # insert text of problems
00686         "Problem text to be displayed. ",
00687         "Enter 1 in this blank:",
00688         ANS_RULE(1,30)      # ANS_RULE() defines an answer blank 30 characters long.
00689                             # It is defined in F<PGbasicmacros.pl>
00690     );
00691     
00692     ANS(answer_evalutors);  # see F<PGanswermacros.pl> for examples of answer evaluatiors.
00693     
00694     ENDDOCUMENT()           # must be the last statement in the problem
00695 
00696 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00697 
00698 This file provides the fundamental macros that define the PG language. It
00699 maintains a problem's text, header text, and answers:
00700 
00701 =over
00702 
00703 =item *
00704 
00705 Problem text: The text to appear in the body of the problem. See TEXT()
00706 below.
00707 
00708 =item *
00709 
00710 Header text: When a problem is processed in an HTML-based display mode,
00711 this variable can contain text that the caller should place in the HEAD of the
00712 resulting HTML page. See HEADER_TEXT() below.
00713 
00714 =item *
00715 
00716 Implicitly-labeled answers: Answers that have not been explicitly
00717 assigned names, and are associated with their answer blanks by the order in
00718 which they appear in the problem. These types of answers are designated using
00719 the ANS() macro.
00720 
00721 =item *
00722 
00723 Explicitly-labeled answers: Answers that have been explicitly assigned
00724 names with the LABELED_ANS() macro, or a macro that uses it. An explicitly-
00725 labeled answer is associated with its answer blank by name.
00726 
00727 =item *
00728 
00729 "Extra" answers: Names of answer blanks that do not have a 1-to-1
00730 correspondance to an answer evaluator. For example, in matrix problems, there
00731 will be several input fields that correspond to the same answer evaluator.
00732 
00733 =back
00734 
00735 =head1 USAGE
00736 
00737 This file is automatically loaded into the namespace of every PG problem. The
00738 macros within can then be called to define the structure of the problem.
00739 
00740 DOCUMENT() should be the first executable statement in any problem. It
00741 initializes vriables and defines the problem environment.
00742 
00743 ENDDOCUMENT() must be the last executable statement in any problem. It packs
00744 up the results of problem processing for delivery back to WeBWorK.
00745 
00746 The HEADER_TEXT(), TEXT(), and ANS() macros add to the header text string,
00747 body text string, and answer evaluator queue, respectively.
00748 
00749 =over
00750 
00751 =item HEADER_TEXT()
00752 
00753  HEADER_TEXT("string1", "string2", "string3");
00754 
00755 HEADER_TEXT() concatenates its arguments and appends them to the stored header
00756 text string. It can be used more than once in a file.
00757 
00758 The macro is used for material which is destined to be placed in the HEAD of
00759 the page when in HTML mode, such as JavaScript code.
00760 
00761 Spaces are placed between the arguments during concatenation, but no spaces are
00762 introduced between the existing content of the header text string and the new
00763 content being appended.
00764 
00765 
00766 
00767 =item TEXT()
00768 
00769  TEXT("string1", "string2", "string3");
00770 
00771 TEXT() concatenates its arguments and appends them to the stored problem text
00772 string. It is used to define the text which will appear in the body of the
00773 problem. It can be used more than once in a file.
00774 
00775 This macro has no effect if rendering has been stopped with the STOP_RENDERING()
00776 macro.
00777 
00778 This macro defines text which will appear in the problem. All text must be
00779 passed to this macro, passed to another macro that calls this macro, or included
00780 in a BEGIN_TEXT/END_TEXT block, which uses this macro internally. No other
00781 statements in a PG file will directly appear in the output. Think of this as the
00782 "print" function for the PG language.
00783 
00784 Spaces are placed between the arguments during concatenation, but no spaces are
00785 introduced between the existing content of the header text string and the new
00786 content being appended.
00787 
00788 
00789 
00790 =item ANS()
00791 
00792  TEXT(ans_rule(), ans_rule(), ans_rule());
00793  ANS($answer_evaluator1, $answer_evaluator2, $answer_evaluator3);
00794 
00795 Adds the answer evaluators listed to the list of unlabeled answer evaluators.
00796 They will be paired with unlabeled answer rules (a.k.a. answer blanks) in the
00797 order entered. This is the standard method for entering answers.
00798 
00799 In the above example, answer_evaluator1 will be associated with the first
00800 answer rule, answer_evaluator2 with the second, and answer_evaluator3 with the
00801 third. In practice, the arguments to ANS() will usually be calls to an answer
00802 evaluator generator such as the cmp() method of MathObjects or the num_cmp()
00803 macro in L<PGanswermacros.pl>.
00804 
00805 
00806 
00807 =item LABELED_ANS()
00808 
00809  TEXT(labeled_ans_rule("name1"), labeled_ans_rule("name2"));
00810  LABELED_ANS(name1 => answer_evaluator1, name2 => answer_evaluator2);
00811 
00812 Adds the answer evaluators listed to the list of labeled answer evaluators.
00813 They will be paired with labeled answer rules (a.k.a. answer blanks) in the
00814 order entered. This allows pairing of answer evaluators and answer rules that
00815 may not have been entered in the same order.
00816 
00817 
00818 
00819 
00820 =item STOP_RENDERING()
00821 
00822  STOP_RENDERING() unless all_answers_are_correct();
00823 
00824 Temporarily suspends accumulation of problem text and storing of answer blanks
00825 and answer evaluators until RESUME_RENDERING() is called.
00826 
00827 
00828 
00829 =item RESUME_RENDERING()
00830 
00831  RESUME_RENDERING();
00832 
00833 Resumes accumulating problem text and storing answer blanks and answer
00834 evaluators. Reverses the effect of STOP_RENDERING().
00835 
00836 
00837 
00838 =item ENDDOCUMENT()
00839 
00840  ENDDOCUMENT();
00841 
00842 When PG problems are evaluated, the result of evaluating the entire problem is
00843 interpreted as the return value of ENDDOCUMENT(). Therefore, ENDDOCUMENT() must
00844 be the last executable statement of every problem. It can only appear once. It
00845 returns a list consisting of:
00846 
00847 
00848 
00849 
00850 =item *
00851 
00852 A reference to a string containing the rendered text of the problem.
00853 
00854 =item *
00855 
00856 A reference to a string containing text to be placed in the HEAD block
00857 when in and HTML-based mode (e.g. for JavaScript).
00858 
00859 =item *
00860 
00861 A reference to the hash mapping answer labels to answer evaluators.
00862 
00863 =item *
00864 
00865 A reference to a hash containing various flags:
00866 
00867 
00868 
00869 =item *
00870 
00871 C<showPartialCorrectAnswers>: determines whether students are told which of their answers in a problem are wrong.
00872 
00873 =item *
00874 
00875 C<recordSubmittedAnswers>: determines whether students submitted answers are saved.
00876 
00877 =item *
00878 
00879 C<refreshCachedImages>: determines whether the cached image of the problem in typeset mode is always refreshed
00880 (i.e. setting this to 1 means cached images are not used).
00881 
00882 =item *
00883 
00884 C<solutionExits>: indicates the existence of a solution.
00885 
00886 =item *
00887 
00888 C<hintExits>: indicates the existence of a hint.
00889 
00890 =item *
00891 
00892 C<comment>: contents of COMMENT commands if any.
00893 
00894 =item *
00895 
00896 C<showHintLimit>: determines the number of attempts after which hint(s) will be shown
00897 
00898 =item *
00899 
00900 C<PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE>: a reference to the chosen problem grader.
00901 ENDDOCUMENT chooses the problem grader as follows:
00902 
00903 =over
00904 
00905 =item *
00906 
00907 If a problem grader has been chosen in the problem by calling
00908 C<install_problem_grader(\&grader)>, it is used.
00909 
00910 =item *
00911 
00912 Otherwise, if the C<PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE> PG environment variable
00913 contains a reference to a subroutine, it is used.
00914 
00915 =item *
00916 
00917 Otherwise, if the C<PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE> PG environment variable
00918 contains the string C<std_problem_grader> or the string C<avg_problem_grader>,
00919 C<&std_problem_grader> or C<&avg_problem_grader> are used. These graders are defined
00920 in L<PGanswermacros.pl>.
00921 
00922 =item *
00923 
00924 Otherwise, the PROBLEM_GRADER_TO_USE flag will contain an empty value
00925 and the PG translator should select C<&std_problem_grader>.
00926 
00927 =back
00928 
00929 =back
00930 
00931 
00932 
00933 =cut
00934 
00935 
00936 ################################################################################
00937 
00938 =head1 PRIVATE MACROS
00939 
00940 These macros should only be used by other macro files. In practice, they are
00941 used exclusively by L<PGbasicmacros.pl>.
00942 
00943 =over
00944 
00945 =item inc_ans_rule_count()
00946 
00947 DEPRECATED 
00948 
00949 Increments the internal count of the number of answer blanks that have been
00950 defined ($ans_rule_count) and returns the new count. This should only be used
00951 when one is about to define a new answer blank, for example with NEW_ANS_NAME().
00952 
00953 =cut
00954 
00955 =item RECORD_ANS_NAME()
00956 
00957  RECORD_ANS_NAME("label", "VALUE");
00958 
00959 Records the label for an answer blank. Used internally by L<PGbasicmacros.pl>
00960 to record the order of explicitly-labelled answer blanks.
00961 
00962 =cut
00963 
00964 =item NEW_ANS_NAME()
00965 
00966  NEW_ANS_NAME();
00967 
00968 Generates an anonymous answer label from the internal count The label is
00969 added to the list of implicity-labeled answers. Used internally by
00970 L<PGbasicmacros.pl> to generate labels for unlabeled answer blanks.
00971 
00972 =cut
00973 
00974 =item ANS_NUM_TO_NAME()
00975 
00976  ANS_NUM_TO_NAME($num);
00977 
00978 Generates an answer label from the supplied answer number, but does not add it
00979 to the list of inplicitly-labeled answers. Used internally by
00980 L<PGbasicmacros.pl> in generating answers blanks that use radio buttons or
00981 check boxes. (This type of answer blank uses multiple HTML INPUT elements with
00982 the same label, but the label should only be added to the list of implicitly-
00983 labeled answers once.)
00984 
00985 =cut
00986 
00987 =item RECORD_FROM_LABEL()
00988 
00989  RECORD_FORM_LABEL("label");
00990 
00991 Stores the label of a form field in the "extra" answers list. This is used to
00992 keep track of answer blanks that are not associated with an answer evaluator.
00993 
00994 =cut
00995 
00996 =item NEW_ANS_ARRAY_NAME()
00997 
00998  NEW_ANS_ARRAY_NAME($num, $row, $col);
00999 
01000 Generates a new answer label for an array (vector) element and adds it to the
01001 list of implicitly-labeled answers.
01002 
01003 =cut
01004 
01005 =item NEW_ANS_ARRAY_NAME_EXTENSION()
01006 
01007  NEW_ANS_ARRAY_NAME_EXTENSION($num, $row, $col);
01008 
01009 Generate an additional answer label for an existing array (vector) element and
01010 add it to the list of "extra" answers.
01011 
01012 =cut
01013 
01014 =item get_PG_ANSWERS_HASH()
01015 
01016  get_PG_ANSWERS_HASH();
01017  get_PG_ANSWERS_HASH($key);
01018 
01019 
01020 
01021 =cut
01022 
01023 =item includePGproblem($filePath)
01024 
01025  includePGproblem($filePath);
01026 
01027  Essentially runs the pg problem specified by $filePath, which is
01028  a path relative to the top of the templates directory.  The output
01029  of that problem appears in the given problem.
01030 
01031 =cut
01032 
01033 =back
